title: How many countries will have a manned, fixed-wing, military aircraft downed in the CENTCOM area of responsibility before 2018?
preds:
Comments: SY loses another aircraft in combat op.
RT, December 26, 'Syrian military jet downed by militants, pilot killed': https://www.rt.com/news/414285-syria-warplane-downed-pilot/ Final comments: GJO November 14 clarification assumes aircraft downed in combat ops. Adjusting forecast due to clarification and time left on this IFP.
Going 100 just because I think another plane isn't getting shot down in the next four days.

If a fixed wing aircraft is downed it will most likely be an accident involving routine operation of US aircraft, due to the frequency of operations and fatigue from high operational tempo. There will be no aerial combat.
Trouble is that only Syria will admit to having a plane downed by a hostile act. Not a good question.
Shifting hard toward 1 because we don't have a lot of time left and I don't see what conflict in the CENTCOM area would result in a plane being shot down.
Syria had 2, so that's 1 country so far right?

Based on the clarification from the admins. They only count 1 country (Syria), in which they only count 2 instances of downings based on corroborated reports. Given that, I don't see this getting above 1 country.

Based on the articles available and some estimates, the probability of 0 countries with downed aircraft is close to zero; 1, 2, or 3 aircraft is a higher probability, but as the number of countries increases, the probability falls after 3 countries with aircraft down.
Sorties are down 60% from last month. Fewer shoot down chances now.

Changing my forecast given recent events in Saudi Arabia and Yemen. The shootdown of a Houthi-launched missile aimed at Riyadh changes things. First of all, this is the first instance I know of of the Houthis launching a ballistic missile against a civilian targets. The Houthis and their Iranian sponsors must have know that such an attack - even an unsuccessful one - would provoke an increased level of retaliation by the Saudis.  Moreover, the apparent consolidation of power by Prince Muhammad bin Salman (an early advocate of the Yemen intervention) and the resignation (forced or not) by Hariri of Lebanon, give the impression that Saudi Arabia may be upping its game against Iran. The Saudi government has used the term "act of war" with reference to the missile attack. Here's an article detailing Saudi responses to the attack: http://time.com/5010997/saudi-coalition-yemen-ports-missile/ All of this to say that there may be an escalation of hostilities, at least in and over Yemen. The Iranians insist that the missile launched by the Houthis against Riyadh was locally produced, not shipped to Yemen by Iran. This is obviously nonsense, but if the Iranians gave them the surface-to-surface missiles to hit Riyadh, they almost certainly gave the Houthis the surface-to-air assets to protect them. If events continue to heat up, there could be some shootdowns of fixed-wing aircraft over Yemen in the near future.
Dateline 11-1-2017 Syria reportedly fires surface-to-air missiles after Israeli jets seen circling area near Lebanon-Syria border -- https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/1.820530

Updating my list. Sitting at consensus until we get clarification. Countries with planes that crashed in CENTCOM area since 23 May 2017: Pakistan (accident): https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/pakistan-air-force-jet-crashes-during-routine-operation-pilot-dead-1736069 US: (accident) https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-12/fighter-jet-crash-lands-at-bahrain-airport
(accident) http://www.military.com/daily-news/2017/09/29/v-22-osprey-crashes-in-syria-2-us-troops-injured-official-says.html Syria: (shoot-down) https://nypost.com/2017/06/18/us-shoots-down-syrian-air-force-fighter/
https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=es&u=https://mundo.sputniknews.com/orientemedio/201708151071586204-avion-siria-desierto-terroristas/&prev=search Saudi Arabia: (shoot-down?, source may not be reliable) http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/yemen-s-houthi-rebels-shoot-down-saudi-led-coalition-typhoon-jet-117102800112_1.html
(reason unclear) https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2017/9/14/saudi-pilot-dies-during-operation-against-al-qaeda-in-yemen
(reason unclear) https://www.inquisitr.com/opinion/4587440/was-a-saudi-typhoon-jet-actually-shot-down-in-yemen/ UAE: (reason unclear, also unclear if this is a fixed-wing aircraft)  http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/08/12/uae-says-4-soldiers-killed-in-yemen-helicopter-crash.html There is also an incident in which a Syrian anti-aircraft missile may have damaged an Israeli jet and forced it to return to base. Not clear if that would be a shoot-down if it had a controlled landing. In any case, Israel says it was a bird strike, so no confirmation. Thanks to @Rene @Gibson and @aaseawaf15 for contributions. @dsarin
@praedico raises some q's about question definition to which i dunno the answer.

@Rene
https://web.archive.org/web/20171028171750/https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Yemeni-Forces-Intercept-Saudi-Typhoon-Fighter-Jet-20171028-0003.html "A Saudi F-15 fighter jet was also shot down over Sana’a in June."
this would tend to validate the June incident that had proved difficult to confirm. I don't know whether the source will qualify (socialist, state-funded media backed by Venezuela (a country seemingly allied with Iran/China/Russia) among others):
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telesur_(TV_channel) For comparison, one of the articles given as an example of what would count in the summary is from Gulf News, but quoting a Yemeni rebel television station, Al Masirah. (GulfNews is a Dubai, i.e., UAE-based outlet. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_News) comment: I surmise that UAE and Saudi Arabia's policy is to say their warplanes crash "for technical reasons" without confirming or denying whether they were shot down (see the Gulf News article above that quotes both Saudi Arabia and Al Masirah). There have been several incidents in which UAE or Saudi aircraft crashed this year in which the country to whom the aircraft belong blamed the crashes on "technical reasons" but most accounts I've seen did not include explicit confirmation from another source that the aircraft was shot down; I do not know for sure whether the judges of this question are able to supply any confirmation beyond public sources, but I tend to assume not.

See discussion to @praedico October 18 post and comments. Up-voted 1. Repeat my earlier comments: advanced AA systems in AOR ups probability of a shoot-down. Recap: 
To date, 2 aircraft downed during combat ops; Syrian jet by USA, RSAF jet in YE Latest:
The New Arab, October 17, 'Two UAE pilots killed in Yemen military plane crash': https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2017/10/18/two-uae-pilots-killed-in-yemen-military-plane-crash  Comments: Hmmmmm,.....
The Aviationist, October 18, 'Israeli Air Force F-35I “Adir” Involved In A Bird Strike Incident Gets Grounded': https://theaviationist.com/2017/10/18/israeli-air-force-f-35i-adir-involved-in-a-bird-strike-incident-gets-grounded/
Clips from Aviationist article:
"The news of the birdstrike incident was released on the very same day the Israeli targeted a Syrian SAM battery that had attacked IDF aircraft during a routine flight over Lebanon fueling speculations that the F-35 was not grounded by a birdstrike but because it was hit by the Syrian air defenses. In fact, the Syrian Defense Ministry said in its statement that government forces responded to the violation of the airspace and “directly hit one of the jets, forcing [Israeli aircraft] to retreat.” On the other side the Israeli denied any aircraft was hit by the Syrian air defenses (S-200 battery) and this sounds quite reasonable considered that the Israeli have often shown their ability to operate freely in the Syrian airspace and there would have been no reason to disclose a fake birdstrike at all to cover a Syrian hit." Global Research, October 17, 'Israel Is Hiding the Fact that Its State of the Art F-35 Warplane Was Hit by Syrian S-200 Missile – Reports': https://www.globalresearch.ca/israel-is-hiding-the-fact-that-its-state-of-the-art-f-35-warplane-was-hit-by-syrian-s-200-missile-reports/5613807
Clips from Research article:
"According to the available information, the Syrian Defense Forces used a S-200 missile against the Israeli warplane. This Soviet-made missile is the most advanced long range anti-aircraft system opearated by the Syrian military. Even in this case, it’s old-fashioned in terms of the modern warfare.
Despite this, the Syrian Defense Ministry said in its statement that government forces responded to the violation of the airspace and “directly hit one of the jets, forcing [Israeli aircraft] to retreat.” This statement contradicts to the Israeli claim that “no hit” was confirmed.
Few hours after the missile incident with Syria, the Israeli media reported that the Israeli Air Force’s F-35 stealth multirole fighter went unserviceable as a result of an alleged bird collision during a training flight.
The incident allegedly took place “two weeks ago” but was publicly reported only on October 16. However, Israeli sources were not able to show a photo of the F-35 warplane after the “bird collision”.
Furthermore, it is not clear if the F-35 can become operational again because its stealth coating was damaged. Thus, according to the Israeli version, the warplane reportedly became no longer operational after the bird collision despite the fact that the F-35 earlier passed the bird strike certification with great results (official info here). The F-35 is the world’s most expensive warplane. The price of developing the F-35 is now about $406.5 billion." CYA. Adjusting mix.

Countries in CENTCOM Area of Responsibility: Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, Iraq, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Yemen, Oman, UAE, Qatar, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan. We need clarification. "Downed" sounds like the aircraft must be actively and deliberately forced to crash or crash-land. But one of the examples that GJO provides is of a plane that crashed due to mechanical failure. There have been  a number of such incidents since 23 May, when this question opened. Countries with planes downed in CENTCOM area so far: Pakistan: https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/pakistan-air-force-jet-crashes-during-routine-operation-pilot-dead-1736069 US: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-12/fighter-jet-crash-lands-at-bahrain-airport
http://www.military.com/daily-news/2017/09/29/v-22-osprey-crashes-in-syria-2-us-troops-injured-official-says.html Syria: https://nypost.com/2017/06/18/us-shoots-down-syrian-air-force-fighter/
https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=es&u=https://mundo.sputniknews.com/orientemedio/201708151071586204-avion-siria-desierto-terroristas/&prev=search Saudi Arabia:https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2017/9/14/saudi-pilot-dies-during-operation-against-al-qaeda-in-yemen Four countries so far and still time for the Syrians to figure out how to hit one of those Israeli reconnaissance planes. Also, US has armed Syrian "rebels" with more powerful anti-aircraft weaponry, so increased chance of hitting a Russian plane as well. And anyone can have an accidental crash. Still, answer is probably 4-5. Clarification request sent. Thanks to @aaseawaf15 for some of the links.

Syria is trying to make that 2 piloted warplanes downed, and Israel is doing its share of escalating warplane vs antiaircraft incidents. Israel is seeing Washingon as an unreliable ally , and therefore is increasing its attacks in the region. Given Russia's decision to give Syria its S-400 antiaircraft hardware, the same hardware that protects Moscow, there is a real, but not huge, possibility (~10%) of destroying an Israeli aircraft. I rate this that low because Israeli pilots are among the best on the planet.  Dateline 10-16-2017  The Israeli army attacked an anti-aircraft battery in Syria, near Damascus, Monday after it fired a missile targeting Israel Air Force planes. The attack was prompted by the launch of an SA5-type missile at Israeli reconnaissance planes. The Syrian missile did not hit its Israeli targets but the Israel Defense Forces decided to hit the battery, the army said.
read more: https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/1.817472

It appears the US has had a drone shot down over Afghanistan.  I will update the prediction if the US releases a statement claiming that it was a malfunction and not a "downing."
http://www.zerohedge.com/news/2017-10-14/us-reaper-drone-shot-down-over-afghanistan Given that Syria has already confirmed the downing of one of their planes, I currently have 100% chance of 2 or more.  Leaving a small chance of two or three more happening in the remaining 6 weeks.
Shifting toward one because, well, its already October.

Comments: Not sure how to class the V-22. We lose another in SY.
Military.com, September 29, '2 Troops Injured in Non-Combat V-22 Crash in Syria': http://www.military.com/daily-news/2017/09/29/v-22-osprey-crashes-in-syria-2-us-troops-injured-official-says.html
Clip from Military article:
"Although the incident was described as a "hard landing," Fox News cited defense officials as saying that the aircraft was destroyed on impact and they expressed amazement that no other troops or crew on board were injured." Comments: IL stepping up air action over SY and LB. Raising probability of a shoot-down.
The Guardian, September 22, 'Israeli jets bombed site close to Damascus airport, reports say- Assad affiliated social media reports say at least two missiles were fired in third attack by Israeli military on targets associated with Hezbollah': https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/sep/22/israeli-jets-bomb-site-close-to-damascus-airport-reports-say
Clips from Guardian article:
"The latest airstrikes mark a recent increase in Israeli interventions which have coincided with diplomatic warnings by the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, that his country will not accept an enhanced Iranian and Hezbollah presence on its northern borders.
While there have been many attacks attributed to Israel in the area around the airport – where there are arms depots associated with weapons that Israel says are being supplied to Hezbollah by Iran – the issue has become more pressing in recent months as it has become clear the Assad regime, backed by Russia, Iran and Hezbollah, is winning on the battlefield.
Israel has made clear it is deeply concerned by a “day after” scenario involving an expanded Iranian and Hezbollah presence to its north.
The latest reported attack comes only days after Israel shot down an Iranian-made drone operated by Hezbollah after it entered the demilitarised zone along the border between Israel and Syria on the Golan Heights. Two weeks ago Israeli warplanes struck a base associated with Syria’s chemical weapons production." Affirming forecast.
One already shot down, but the overall base rate is less than one per year in recent years.
So far, as far as I can tell, anyway, it's still just one - Syria. Adjusting for the passage of time.

http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/saudi-pilot-dies-operation-al-qaida-yemen-49841871 though the language doesn't say "downed" these incidents may qualify per the language in some of the articles given as examples in the question summary.

The Aviationist, September 14, 'A Royal Saudi Air Force Typhoon has crashed in Yemen’s southern province of Abyan, Yemen, killing the pilot': https://theaviationist.com/2017/09/14/saudi-eurofighter-typhoon-crashes-during-combat-mission-in-yemen-killing-the-pilot/ Adjusting mix.

Comments: Adding IL back. Sorties into SY and LB raises risk.
Time of Israel, September 10, 'Israeli jets said to cause sonic boom over Lebanon - Report comes a day after Beirut complained to the UN that IDF planes violated its airspace in raid on Syrian missile plant': https://www.timesofisrael.com/israeli-jets-said-to-cause-sonic-boom-over-lebanon/ Comments: IR vs USA in Gulf. High potential for aerial encounter.
Reuters, September, 'U.S. denies Iran report of confrontation with U.S. vessel': https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-us-gulf/u-s-denies-iran-report-of-confrontation-with-u-s-vessel-idUSKCN1BL08M Affirming forecast.
At a minimum, I expect a Syrian aircraft to go down.  There's a possibility that either an Afghani or Iraqi aircraft will be downed as well.

I am actually not sure what this question is asking. Is it asking how many countries will experience a fixed-wing military aircraft downed within its borders? Or is it asking the number of countries whose planes are downed? For example, if a US plane is downed in Syria and another US plane is downed in Yemen, does that count as two countries or as one?

Affirming forecast for the passage of time. @lsgold7
I got this book yesterday and I'm looking forward to diving into it. While it won't make me a Jack Devine or Frank Archibald, it may make me a better analyst:
Cases in Intelligence Analysis; Structured Analytic Techniques in Action 2nd Edition: https://www.amazon.com/Intelligence-Analysis-Structured-Analytic-Techniques/dp/1483340163/ref=dp_ob_title_bk
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
Is anyone tracking this? Is there a reliable website?

See @aaseawaf15 comment (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/550831), coupled with previous downing of Syrian aircraft (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/517912), which puts the number at 4 (unless one of them doesn't count for reasons unknown - hence the 5% in the 2-3 category).

Comments: Okay, by the numbers....... 27 countries in CENTCOM AOR..... fixed-wing military aircraft downed...... quick search for news, here we go. Scratching IL since part of EUCOM AOR:  ABC News, August 12, 'US fighter jet crash lands at Bahrain International Airport': http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/fighter-jet-crash-lands-bahrain-airport-49174616 NDTV, August 10, 'Pakistan Air Force Jet Crashes During Routine Operation; Pilot Dead': http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/pakistan-air-force-jet-crashes-during-routine-operation-pilot-dead-1736069 ABC News, August 3, 'Pilot, 2 trainees dead in military plane crash in Djibouti': http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/pilot-trainees-dead-military-plane-crash-djibouti-49012947 Adjusting mix. Related:
Airforce-Technology.com, J-7 / F-7 Fighter Aircraft, China: http://www.airforce-technology.com/projects/j7f7fighteraircraft/
The J-7 is a single-engine, lightweight fighter aircraft designed and manufactured by Chengdu Aircraft Corporation (CAC) of China. Its design is based on its predecessor, the MiG-21 aircraft. The export version of J-7 has been designated the F-7.

Reuters, July 29, 'Eastern Libya force jet shot down by missile over Derna: official': https://www.reuters.com/article/us-libya-security-idUSKBN1AE0ND
Clip from Reuters article:
"A MiG-21 fighter was shot down by a missile after the aircraft carried out an airstrike targeting militants," LNA spokesman for the Benina air base, Naser Hassi, told Reuters."  Affirming forecast.
because you cant really control 4 million square miles documented and 550 million people. because people like to shoot at an "enemy'
AT ATTACK SPEED most of these aircraft can make it to base in literally 2 mins if it holds togeather.

Comments: Good news = The Caliphate is toast, with Mosul and Raqqa I expect to fall by summer's end. 
Bad news = The real fun begins when ALL actors involved start (if not already) readying for Round 2 when carving out/expanding/maintaining 'spheres-of-influences' in the region. See a RISE in 'hostile encounters' between major and secondary actors in the coming months. Newsweek, July 3, 'THE NEXT MIDDLE EAST WAR? HEZBOLLAH MAY RISK EVERYTHING IN ALL-OUT FIGHT WITH ISRAEL': http://www.newsweek.com/2017/07/14/middle-east-war-hezbollah-israel-syria-630990.html Where are the significant #s of homeless IS fighters heading to? The EU will be watching closely for these dog turds, so I see 1) North Africa (i.e., Libya, Morocco) 2) NE Africa (i.e., The Sudan, Ethiopia with civil turmoil and/or weak national govts)  3) AF/PAK region. Where these guys go, if they are in sizeable #s, airstrikes are sure to follow.  Lastly, see USA and RU continuation/expansion of airpower use in affected areas for:
1) fire support, both tactical and strategic.
2) force-projection.
3) testing new concepts & weapon systems; sales and marketing (no shit, ...... remember, there's big $ to be made in the global arms trade. Putin ain't stupid).  Related: 
Global Firepower, African Powers Ranked by Military Strength Ranking: http://www.globalfirepower.com/countries-listing-africa.asp Affirming forecast.
cease-fires, if effective, generally trend to less hostility; adjusting slightly for today's news of T&P out of the G20.

Dateline 7-1-2017 "The confrontation with Syria and Russia that led to the shoot-down of a Syrian fighter jet just south of here two weeks ago seems to have eased, at least for now. Despite the Russians’ public protests, they quietly agreed last weekend on a roughly 80-mile “deconfliction” line that stretches from a few miles west of here to a village on the Euphrates called Karama. That line appears to be holding, and it’s a promising sign that broader U.S.-Russian cooperation in Syria may be possible." -- https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/global-opinions/as-the-islamic-state-ees-syria-one-city-offers-a-preview-of-the-countrys-future/2017/06/30/da4c7b4e-5dc3-11e7-9fc6-c7ef4bc58d13_story.html

Since a manned Syrian plane was shot down last week, I am rebalancing toward 2-3 countries this year as there's now a lot of air forces flying in Syria and I wouldn't be surprised at another incident.

Comments: Holy crap!
BBC News, June 20, 'Russian jet 'flies 5ft from' US spy plane over Baltic Sea': http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-40346016
Clips from article:
"The US RC-135 reconnaissance aircraft had been flying with its transponder on, making it visible to other aircraft, he added.
But Russia's defence ministry said it was the US plane that behaved dangerously after it was already intercepted and was being escorted by a Russian Su-27 fighter jet.
"During the escorting, the RC-135 crew made an attempt of closing with the Russian fighter, performing a provocative turnaround toward the Su-27," the TASS news agency quoted the Russian ministry as saying.
About 10 minutes later, another US surveillance plane arrived, and it too was intercepted by a SU-27 jet, the ministry said." Affirming forecast. Heads up, forecasters!

The US just shot down an Iranian drone (second drone in two months) over Syria.  Things are getting hot.

The Russian threat in response to the US led downing of a Syrian plane is having the opposite effect of what I predicted. I initially thought the raised tensions would create more risk for downed planes. However, Australia is now suspending any and all air activity in the area because of this threat: http://mobile.reuters.com/article/idUSKBN19B0GY?il=0 It would not be surprising to see other countries follow suit. Adjusting my forecast the opposite direction, with a fairly significant move towards 2 or 3 countries.

Dateline June 20, 2017 SitRep: U.S., Russia Still Talking in Syria... From: Foreign Policy <fp@foreignpolicy.com>	 Syria ops normal. Mostly. Tensions remain high between the United States and Russia after Sunday’s shoot down of a Syrian jet, and Moscow’s threats to begin tracking all coalition flights west of the Euphrates River with its warplanes and missile defense systems. There’s already been a bit of fallout. Australia announced Tuesday it had suspended its flights into Syria, "as a precautionary measure,” Australia's Department of Defence said in a statement. Strikes continue. A daily roundup of airstrikes released by the U.S. Central Command Tuesday showed eight strikes around Raqqa, which sits directly on the Euphrates. “Coalition aircraft continue to conduct operations [unescorted by Russian aircraft] throughout Syria,” Col. Ryan Dillon, the Baghdad-based spokesman for the U.S.-led coalition fighting ISIS, told SitRep in an email Tuesday. He added that despite Russian claims to have shut down the “hotline” between American and Russian military officers in Syria, “we continue to use the de-confliction line with the Russians. The Coalition is always available to de-conflict with the Russians.”

http://www.haaretz.com/us-news/1.796557 After the US downed a Syrian plane, Russia is now threatening to attack "Any Flying Object" in Syrian airspace. This rise in tensions indicate an increased probability of a downed military plane in the CENTCOM AOR.  Adjusting prediction accordingly.

The pro-Assad regime Syrian Su-22 that was downed had attacked Syrian Democratic Forces aligned with the U.S. led coalition and inflicted casualties on the friendly forces as they were driving south of Tabqah before it was intercepted. The action began at approximately 4:30 PM local time on Sunday, Jun. 18 when Syrian forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad launched a ground attack on anti-regime Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) aligned with the U.S. led Coalition and inflicted casualties on the anti-Assad fighters. Coalition combat aircraft immediately conducted a low-altitude “show of force” pass on the pro-Assad attackers and were successful in de-conflicting the two sides and halting the advance of pro-Assad forces on Coalition-friendly SDF positions. As a result of the contact unspecified Coalition assets utilized a secure communication “de-confliction line” to contact Russian assets with communications to both sides in an effort to compel a cease-fire for both sides. The Russian attempt at de-confliction failed at 6:43 PM local time when a pro-Assad Syrian Air Force Su-22 ground attack aircraft appeared on scene and bombed Coalition-friendly SDF positions. The attacking Syrian Su-22 was “Immediately shot down by a U.S. F/A-18E Super Hornet” 
https://theaviationist.com/tag/su-22-fitter/
Adjusting; it isn't zero any more, and the odds of "Two or three" rose this morning.
I expect tbe Syrian plane downi g has sent a shock wave rhrough the coalition and air controlers will be quite deligent in keeping contacts from occurring, and Assad will be wary  of usaf.

It is not at all likely that the Russians will have permission to shoot down any US, Canadian, Australian, or European aircraft, and Turkey is still a member of NATO for whatever that's worth.  If I were Russia I'd shoot down something out of Jordan, Qatar, Bahrain, or the UAE, just to make the point.  Then I'd declare us even and lay off.  Nobody actually wants to escalate this mess.

cooperation suspension Part II. https://worldview.stratfor.com/situation-report/syria-russia-halts-air-coordination-threatens-shoot-down-coalition-jets
"Russia's Defense Ministry said June 19 it is suspending cooperation to prevent air incidents over Syria with the U.S.-led coalition, a day after a U.S. fighter jet shot down a Syrian government plane near Tabqa, RT reported. In its statement, the Russian Defense Ministry threatened to track and shoot down any coalition planes and drones operating west of the Euphrates river. The U.S. jet downed the Syrian plane after it dropped bombs near fighters from the U.S.-backed Syrian Democratic Forces, the coalition's main ally in the fight against the Islamic State. The incident occurred amid clashes between the U.S.-backed group and loyalist forces, who have have been moving southeast of Tabqa into Islamic State-held territory."

@Rene @rfmgy @Dsarin The US destroyed a Syrian regime SU-22 today. http://www.inherentresolve.mil/News/Article/1208008/coalition-statement-on-at-tanf/ and map at https://syria.liveuamap.com/en/2017/18-june-cjtfoir-statement-on-the-downing-of-a-syrian-su22 So what do you think about increasing likelihood of two or more?

Using Data collected from thin analysis: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/519173
Along with data from wikipedia. Here are my calculations:
There are 117 countries with military aircraft.
There is about a 5.26% chance one of these countries will have action in CENTCOM.
Of these remaining countries, there is a 57.41% chance of a downed plane in this space. 117 x .05263 x .5741 = 3.535 countries

This question is tricky. I asked for clarification as to what constitutes a "downed aircraft." The only reply I received was that the examples provided a "non-exhaustive list of what could count," which was extremely unhelpful. This means that I must clarify my interpretation of GJP's cryptic use of "downed" here. Seeing that the Jordanian, Bahraini, Moroccan, and Saudi aircraft in the Gulf News example were lost due to mechanical or pilot errors, it is clear that this will count as long as the warplanes were actively participating in an operation. This significantly broadens the field, but there is no clarification if a warplane is counted as "downed" while on a training or routine flight, which will skew results. I will continue with the definition as "downed on operation" (including error and mechanical failure) and later discuss training accidents.  1. Syria- Already confirmed. This is no surprise as Syria has lost an average of 8-10 planes for every year of the Syrian Civil War. http://www.businessinsider.com/rebel-forces-say-they-shot-down-a-syrian-jet-near-damascus-2017-6 2. USA- In operations in Iraq and Syria in the past decade, the U.S. has lost 30 planes "downed." This number is exclusively from technical failure or pilot error, but does count. While the 30 does include Operation Iraqi Freedom losses, the recent campaign against IS in Iraq and Syria has claimed an average of 1.67 planes/year since 2014. With a more aggressive U.S. posture against IS and the Syrian government, I think a downing of a U.S. plane to be likely in the given timeline. 3. Russia- Beginning operations in Syria in late 2015, Russia has lost 3 aircraft either shot down or crashed. Considering Russia's ongoing operations in Syria and record of 1.5 planes lost/year, I think this is likely.  3a. Turkey- Also operating in Syrian airspace, the Turks have lost only one jet shot down by Syria in 2012. While the Turks are increasing operations against IS and Kurdish groups in Syria, the realignment of Erdogan with Putin should protect Turkish jets from the Syrian air defense. I do not think a Turkish jet will be lost this year unless this informal alliance is broken. 4/5?) Arab Coalition in Yemen- Saudi Arabia, Jordan, UAE, Bahrain, Morocco et. al. 
This is a very interesting situation, which I think a lot of forecasters are discounting. Since the beginning of the "Arab coalition" air campaign in Yemen in 2015, five aircraft from five nations have been downed, averaging two/year. The air campaign, while significantly reduced, has taken casualties after the initial Operation Decisive Storm, so it is safe to say that at least one plane from one coalition nation will be downed this year (in addition to the Jordanian one in the example). The interesting question is if there will be a second one, which is possible based upon current averages.  Therefore, it is likely that 4 or 5 is the most likely forecast, followed by 2 or 3. It is highly doubtful that only Syria will lose a plane this year.  Honorable mentions: If training crashes in the CENTCOM areas are included, Pakistan would definitely count as they have averaged 1.6 crashes/year for the past decade. Iran averages 0.4/year in losses while Omani and Jordanian (non-combat) losses are at 0.3/year.

"Two Syrian rebels and a war monitor said a Syrian military plane had come down about 50 km east of Damascus on Monday in rebel-held territory near a frontline with government-held land. "We have brought down a Syrian jet in Tel Dakwa area in rural Damascus and we are searching for the pilot," Saad al Haj, spokesman for Western backed Jaish Osoud al Sharqiya rebel group, told Reuters. Osoud al Sharqiya is one of the main groups fighting in the southeast Syrian desert, known as the Badia. Pictures of what appeared to be the human remains of the pilot have been shared on opposition social media sites alongside pictures of aircraft wreckage said to be that of the warplane. Another rebel official, Said Seif from the Western-vetted Ahmed Abdo Martyrs group that operates in the area, said the plane came down in an area 15 kms east of Bir Qasab between Tal Dakwa and Dumair airport. Seif said rebels hit the aircraft with heavy, anti-aircraft machine guns which had been delivered to them in recent weeks by the United States and its allies to fend off a new push into southeast Syria by the government and allied Iran-backed militias. The Syrian military could not be reached for comment. The Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights war monitor said a plane was shot down by a rebel group in the area but it could not confirm if the pilot was dead or alive. Reuters could not independently confirm reports of the downed plane." http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-warplane-idUSKBN18W1RE

The intensity of operations appears to be easing from previous periods, and Russian involvement is also reported winding down. Given that so many civilians have fed to Europe, and the regime is weakened there are little in the way of drivers that will escalate operations in the near future.

CAS Related:
Jerusalem Post, May 25, 'ISRAEL'S EYES IN THE SKY GATHER INTEL IN A SHIFTING MIDDLE EAST - Israel Air Force is fusing manned and unmanned intelligence missions in order to complete the puzzle': http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Rising-threats-lead-IAF-to-fly-more-manned-intelligence-missions-493948 Close air support (CAS): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close_air_support
In military tactics, close air support (CAS) is defined as air action by fixed or rotary-winged aircraft against hostile targets, that are in close proximity to friendly forces, and which requires detailed integration of each air mission with fire and movement of these forces.
The requirement for detailed integration because of proximity, fires or movement is the determining factor. CAS may need to be conducted during shaping operations with Special Operations Forces (SOF), if the mission requires detailed integration with the fire and movement of these forces. A closely related subset of air interdiction, battlefield air interdiction (AI) denotes interdiction against units with near-term effects on friendly units, but which does not require integration with friendly troop movements. The term "battlefield air interdiction" is not currently used in U.S. joint doctrine.
Close air support requires excellent coordination with ground forces. In advanced modern militaries, this coordination is typically handled by specialists such as Joint Fires Observers (JFO)s, Joint Terminal Attack Controllers (JTAC)s, and Forward Air Controllers (FAC)s. Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairchild_Republic_A-10_Thunderbolt_II
The Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II is a single-seat, twin turbofan engine, straight wing jet aircraft developed by Fairchild-Republic for the United States Air Force (USAF). Commonly referred to by the nicknames "Warthog" or "Hog", its official name comes from the Republic P-47 Thunderbolt, a World War II fighter that was effective at attacking ground targets. The A-10 was designed for close air support (CAS) of friendly ground troops, attacking armored vehicles and tanks, and providing quick-action support against enemy ground forces. It entered service in 1976 and is the only production-built aircraft that has served in the USAF that was designed solely for CAS. Its secondary mission is to provide forward air controller – airborne (FAC-A) support, by directing other aircraft in attacks on ground targets. Aircraft used primarily in this role are designated OA-10.
Source: Wikipedia

I go with @danbell7819 (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/508139) and a feeling that 2 is very likely. I interpret the question as @denbell7819 does: a syrian aircraft downed would count as "1", i.e. the first option would mean there is no aircraft downed in the rest of this year... VERY unlikely given the historical record. The base rate clearly favorizes the third option, however! One counts as one only if it is belonging to a new country. The question is which factors help explain the patterns and whether they change throughout the rest of the year. But, generally speaking, there is not much change in the Syrian civil war...

I think this question needs some clarification. I assume "before 2018" means from today until 31 Dec 2017, and excludes any downing prior to today (Syria has already lost aircraft this year). Operating under that assumption, and looking at historical data for the Syrian Civil War (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_aviation_shootdowns_and_accidents_during_the_Syrian_Civil_War), I think it's likely that Syria will have another manned, fixed-wing, military aircraft downed before they year is out. I also think it's fairly likely that Russia will lose another aircraft, given they have lost at least one over the past two years. Three countries (the third being the U.S.) seems less likely, especially since recent U.S. losses have been drones. Four or more countries is highly unlikely, and would be more of a fluke than anything else. I recognize that CENTCOM is larger than Syria, but there's not as many opportunities for aircraft downings outside of unpredictable mechanical failures. Iraq might be another candidate country, but the fight against ISIS appears to be more focused on ground warfare and territorial control that air and anti-air warfare.
